title: Roadmap: from incubation to Core Unit
body:
**Today’s work**

Today I spend some hours mapping how I plan to move from the incubator to running a Core Unit with a minimal viable operation.

The roadmap is available here, and will be changed by me on an ongoing basis: 

[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-Cgqbk8_HQ_C4D680Mzt5sFz8j7vQMDaCZkzo-W1ddo/edit#gid=0](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-Cgqbk8_HQ_C4D680Mzt5sFz8j7vQMDaCZkzo-W1ddo/edit#gid=0)

My three main objectives in the incubation process are as follows:

1. To make an assessment of the legal risks associated with MakerDAO and the CUs.
2. To design a framework for supporting the CUs in their mitigation of risks.
3. Setting up a website for sharing knowledge with relevant stakeholders.

I felt highly motivated working my way through this task. 🔮

**Setting the team**

I am thinking a lot about the people and skills that are needed for making a core unit with a focus on legal resiliency a success.

I also think about how to design the recruitment process.

I believe the best way is to collaborate on one or two tasks with each candidate, to actually assess how we communicate and how our skills play together.

In teammates, I highly value:

* Cultivation of meaningful work and meaningful relationships
* High integrity
* Reflection - thinking before acting
* Radical transparency 
* Curiosity

**A quick thought - you can help me here**

Is anyone making executive summaries of all the meetings going on? I believe the 80/20-rules can be applied to most meetings, meaning it will take 20% effort to understand 80% of the content - which can probably be done by reading good summaries.

This could also be helpful for e.g. delegates that want to be on top of things without getting into all the details.

If no one is writing summaries of the meetings, I will consider hiring for this task. It will save me valuable time that can be spent on 

Please be honest and let me know if you consider this a bad idea! 

 Please also let me know if you see value in this delegation, and if you are interested in receiving a copy of the executive summaries.

title: Technology v. Community
body:
What is most likely to become the moat of smart contract L1’s over the longer term? Assuming network effects are a given for a blockchain that is able to scale; where will the defensible value be created?

* Technology: faster and cheaper transactions that can scale to 1 billion+ users?
* Community: teams building (on top of each other) a wide range of dapps?

2021 showed us we live in a multi-chain reality. Several L1s saw great traction in the past months. This begs the question: How defensible is Ethereum, and if so, which components of the network? Will ETH remain the dominant general purpose blockchain, in spite of higher fees and slower TPS? Will L2’s bring the require performance for ETH to stay competitive on speed and fees?

Given the pace of innovation, newer chains appear to beat ETH on those aspects, although one can counter that ETH is more decentralized. Leaving values aside, newer L1s are showing signs of superior engineering.

Where ETH remains the strongest is the ecosystem of dapps that have been built on top the protocol. This is what attracts money, users, and builders, in turn driving more transactions on the the network.

Blockchain technology will become commoditized. Beyond a certain threshold of speed, fees and decentralization, any improvements will see decreasing value to users. I’m will to bet that In a few years we might well live in a world where there are many chains that perform on a similar level, all of them finding meaningful adoption. They will be interchangeable. The brand value of a chain won’t come from technical prowess. Block space availability will not remain as scarce as it is today.

BUT here’s the thing: People, i.e. users and developers, can’t spend their time and attention in many places at once. Attention is the scarcest resource. We can’t shard it, we can’t scale it with L2s. Humans can only spend a finite amount of their attention is one place at the time.

They will go to the network where they get the most utility. They won’t want to switch once they are all set up in their ways. Especially when a network’s value is seeing strong network effects.

Attention is scarce, computing is abundant. Attention is largely fixed while blockchains get faster every year. Attention can’t be forked, protocols can.

title: Roadmap: from incubation to Core Unit
body:
**Today’s work**

Today I spend some hours mapping how I plan to move from the incubator to running a Core Unit with a minimal viable operation.

The roadmap is available here, and will be changed by me on an ongoing basis: 

[https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-Cgqbk8_HQ_C4D680Mzt5sFz8j7vQMDaCZkzo-W1ddo/edit#gid=0](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-Cgqbk8_HQ_C4D680Mzt5sFz8j7vQMDaCZkzo-W1ddo/edit#gid=0)

My three main objectives in the incubation process are as follows:

1. To make an assessment of the legal risks associated with MakerDAO and the CUs.
2. To design a framework for supporting the CUs in their mitigation of risks.
3. Setting up a website for sharing knowledge with relevant stakeholders.

I felt highly motivated working my way through this task. 🔮

**Setting the team**

I am thinking a lot about the people and skills that are needed for making a core unit with a focus on legal resiliency a success.

I also think about how to design the recruitment process.

I believe the best way is to collaborate on one or two tasks with each candidate, to actually assess how we communicate and how our skills play together.

In teammates, I highly value:

* Cultivation of meaningful work and meaningful relationships
* High integrity
* Reflection - thinking before acting
* Radical transparency 
* Curiosity

**A quick thought - you can help me here**

Is anyone making executive summaries of all the meetings going on? I believe the 80/20-rules can be applied to most meetings, meaning it will take 20% effort to understand 80% of the content - which can probably be done by reading good summaries.

This could also be helpful for e.g. delegates that want to be on top of things without getting into all the details.

If no one is writing summaries of the meetings, I will consider hiring for this task. It will save me valuable time that can be spent on strategic and operational tasks.

Please be honest and let me know if you consider this a bad idea! 

 Please also let me know if you see value in this delegation, and if you are interested in receiving a copy of the executive summaries.

HASH DAO Governance seeks to be the future industry standard.

**Problem**

Funding for a successful craft cannabis brand with artisanal quality creates struggles to navigate the extractive nature of the traditional corporate company structure. Typically the capital solutions available often compromise the integrity and quality of the products at the expense of the small brands reputation, consumers, and the Earth.

Malpractice and gatekeeping of the cannabis industry has traditionally maximized profits at the cost of the plant or people, and in turn have provided barriers to entry to craft cannabis farmers and the BIPOC community.

*Barriers of Entry + (Profit > People) = Current State of the Cannabis Space*

**Solution**

The majority of the craft cannabis industry, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the consumer, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly penalized small legacy growers. Incarceration of marginalized communities for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in. Certain strains go on to become culturally iconic that generate massive value. Often times the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

Current Stakeholders in the Cannabis Space :

* Breeders, Growers, & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

Although track-and-trace is currently implemented, most cannabis brands are not completely transparent with their grow methods and techniques of production. There is also massive risk for current cannabis businesses as they have become targets for robberies the past few years. Legal brands are facing counterfeits and knock-offs in the black market. With the integration of digital identities, NFTs/Web3 purchasing, and automation, many of these problems are easily solved.

Create community-ownership of the vertically-integrated HASH DAO supply chain of production, processing, distributing, and operating on-chain craft cannabis compliance geared toward Web3 adoption. **Data Privacy & Security**

Privacy is essential to any business. Surprisingly, it is almost nonexistent in the blockchain ecosystem. For example, Bitcoin started out with privacy as a goal but was subverted and now is very public by using \[chain analytics companies\](https://bitcoinist.com/yes-your-bitcoin-transactions-can-be-tracked-and-here-are-the-companies that-are-doing-it/.). It's like having your bank account available to the public where the public cannot access your money but they can see everything you are doing. The same is true of smart contract platforms like Ethereum.

Hash DAO will use the most private smart contract platform soon-to-be available, [DERO](https://www.dero.com/).

Bitcoin's privacy problem was solved by the cryptocurrency coin Monero. Similarly, Ethereum’s privacy problem is solved by the token DERO.

Many blockchain projects, both cryptocurrency coins and and smart contract platforms using tokens, claim privacy but in fact are not. They offer a privacy option at best. This in fact defeats true privacy which only exists when the project offers *privacy by default at the protocol level*.

Creating a future:

* Geared to the love and cultivation of the plant and Mother Earth
* Onboarding BIPOC leaders and creatives onto the blockchain
* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

Reinvention of the Horticulture Supply Chain and Data Distribution via smart contracts that allow for automation and help individuals to create ownership over community-led projects, intellectual property, digital assets, and dApps.

The distribution and delivery will be a warehouse that will have an on-chain ESG-metric system in the back and a public access immersive art space in the front. We will also be looking into developing a portfolio of boutique cannabis bud and breakfasts in emerging global cannabis markets.

**Project #7 :** We will be finding ERP solutions to develop state-of-the-art horticulture automation and Web3 technologies, based upon on-chain governance and compliance, to pave the way for the international industry standard by working towards meeting ESG-metric compliance. The majority of the craft cannabis industry, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the consumer, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly penalized small legacy growers. Incarceration of marginalized communities for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in. Certain strains go on to become culturally iconic that generate massive value. Often times the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

* Breeders, Growers, & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

Privacy is essential to any business. Surprisingly, it is almost nonexistent in the blockchain ecosystem. For example, Bitcoin started out with privacy as a goal but was subverted and now is very public by using \[chain analytics companies\](https://bitcoinist.com/yes-your-bitcoin-transactions-can-be-tracked-and-here-are-the-companies that-are-doing-it/.). It's like having your bank account available to the public where the public cannot access your money but they can see everything you are doing. Hash DAO will use the most private smart contract platform soon-to-be available, [DERO](https://www.dero.com/).

Bitcoin's privacy problem was solved by the cryptocurrency coin Monero. Similarly, Ethereum’s privacy problem is solved by the token DERO.

Many blockchain projects, both cryptocurrency coins and and smart contract platforms using tokens, claim privacy but in fact are not. They offer a privacy option at best. This in fact defeats true privacy which only exists when the project offers *privacy by default at the protocol level*.

* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

title: Technology v. Community
body:
What is most likely to become the moat of smart contract L1/L2 blockchains over the longer term? Assuming network effects are a given for a blockchain that is able to scale; where will the defensible value be created?

* **Technology**: faster and cheaper transactions that can scale to 1 billion+ users?
* **Community**: teams building (on top of each other) a wide range of dapps?

2021 showed us we live in a multi-chain reality. Several L1s saw great traction in the past months.

This begs the question: How defensible is Ethereum’s ecosystem? Which components of the network provide a competitive lever? Will Ethereum L1 chains remain the dominant general purpose blockchain, in spite of higher fees and slower TPS as we move to a roll-up centric world?

Given the pace of innovation, newer chains appear to beat ETH on those aspects, although one can counter that ETH is more decentralized. Leaving values aside, newer L1s are showing signs of superior engineering.

Where ETH remains the strongest is the ecosystem of dapps that have been built on top the protocol. This is what attracts money, attention, users, and builders, in turn driving more transactions on the the network.

Blockchain technology will become commoditized. Beyond a certain threshold of speed, fees and decentralization, any improvements will see decreasing value to users. I’m will to bet that in a few years we might well live in a world where there are many chains that perform on a similar level, all of them finding meaningful adoption. They will be interchangeable. Users won’t know and won’t care which blockchain is being used in under the hood. The brand value of a chain won’t come from technical prowess. Block space availability will not remain as scarce as it is today.

BUT here’s the thing: People, i.e. users and developers, can’t spend their time and attention in many places at once. **Attention is the scarcest resource.** We can’t shard it, we can’t scale it with L2s. Humans can only spend a finite amount of their attention is one place at the time.

They will go to the network where they get the most utility. They won’t want to switch once they formed a specific habit around a chain. Especially when a network’s value is seeing strong network effects.

Attention is scarce, computing is abundant. Attention is largely fixed, blockchains get faster every year. Attention can’t be forked, protocols can. 
 For those reasons, I put ecosystem ahead of technology.

But the reality isn’t neatly black and white. Technology does enable new use cases that wouldn’t be possible in the past. Interoperability across protocols is also key in driving utility, which in turn drives network effects.

title: The Firewall Saga - Synopsis
body:
Set twenty-five thousand years after the apocalypse, The Firewall Saga tells the story of Earth divided in two by a wall of nuclear fire that encircles the equator.

The Northern Hemisphere has been turned into a radioactive wasteland with most of its landmass left inhospitable to life and vast swathes of the oceans boiled off into the atmosphere. The relatively advanced infrastructure of the early 21st century nation-states allowed small pockets of human civilization to survive with much of their scientific knowledge intact. Over the subsequent millennia, the northern survivors have managed to consolidate and advance the progress of civilization. Unfortunately, the reality of scorched earth has pushed the boundaries of what even the most advanced scientific understanding can achieve, and their survival now depends on crossing the Firewall into the unknown Southern Hemisphere...

...where the effects of the creation of the Firewall could not have been more different. The initial cataclysm was as devastating to the South as it was to the North; however, radiation was limited to a narrow band close to the equator, leaving much of the landmass habitable. With the near-total destruction of human civilization, the southern hemisphere's eco-systems have been able to bounce back from the cataclysm and have turned the south into a thriving biome. Humanity has managed to hang on, but the progress of the 21st century was lost and the cultures that now thrive are tribal and barbaric.

Book 1 of the saga, Emberlight, tells the story of the Northerner's attempts to breach the Firewall and explore the South, following the adventures of Antigua and her robotic steed as they explore this uncharted part of the world. It follows her encounters with southern natives whose primitive, nomadic ways are as alien to her as her cyber-enhanced bio-armour and robot horse are to them. Can these two races, once a single world population, reunite and thrive again? 

Or will the clash of cultures result in a global war?

title: Mock testing your smart contracts.
body:
![](https://vuejsdevelopers.com/images/posts/jest_mock.jpg)

Mock Testing allows you to isolate and test your code in different states without interference. To put it simply, we replace our original object with the mock object with the modified conditions that we want to test. This makes the unit testing for those conditions very smooth.

**Note:** Some smart-contract development and familiarity with Openzeppelin contracts will help you follow this article. The project I used for the demo is built with [Foundry](https://getfoundry.sh/), but you can use any other tools (e.g., Hardhat and Brownie) as I outline in this article.

[https://github.com/PradhumnaPancholi/Figbot](https://github.com/PradhumnaPancholi/Figbot)

## Goal

Imagine you have an NFT (non-fungible token) contract with a maximum supply of 100. How do you test that this contract will not mint more than 100? What if it is a set of 10,000? We don’t want to deploy our contracts untested. The same goes for the limit of your ERC-20 tokens, treasuries, staking pools, etc. Situations like these are where mock testing your contract is essential. And that is exactly what we will be going through in this article.

**Order of operations:**

1. Set up an NFT contract with a maximum supply of 100.
2. Mock the contract with the state of `tokenId` being 100.
3. Write unit-test to `mint` token after max supply is reached.

## Project Setup

For this project, we will be using a repository that I created a few days ago for my article on [Foundry](https://getfoundry.sh/) basics. But you can use any smart contract development tool like Hardhat, Truffle, or Brownie. Let’s take a quick look at the contract. It is a simple foundry project for an NFT called Figbot. First, we install Openzeppelin to use the `Ownable`, `ERC721URIStorage`,  and `Counters` module for our NFT.

![src/Figbot.sol](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/YOimsPz51r8SxEHJgEqJ2.png?height=1080&width=1920)

As you can see, we have :

1. Implemented `Counters.sol` to help us with `tokenIds`
2. State variables for `MAX_SUPPLY`, `COST`, and `TOKEN_URI`
3. Setup `constructor` for ERC721
4. An event to broadcast when `withdrawFunds` function is successfully executed
5. Written functions for `mint`, `totalSupply`, and `withdrawFunds`

## Mocking the contract

Now, we will mock our contract to test that no one can mint any more than the max supply. Our NFT contract has a maximum supply of 100 tokens. We need to manipulate our state in this mocked contract to test that. As you can see, we are using `Counters` to index `tokenIds`. I am going to demonstrate two approaches to accomplish this.

Let’s create a mocks directory inside our src directory (inside the contracts directory if you are using Hardhat or Brownie). Now, create a file called FigbotMock.sol inside the mocks directory. To set up the mock, we need to perform the following:

1. Import the contract we intend to mock.
2. Import the libraries that are being used in the contract.
3. Declare the mock contract by inheriting the base contract.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wbLbOzTv88wZ9EPP1_2Qc.png?height=1080&width=1920)

Now, I will show you two approaches to handle this, and you will find yourself using both of these depending on the case. Later on in the article, I will explain preferences and what to look out for.

### The function that updates state:

As I mentioned earlier, we use `Counters.sol` from Openzeppelin contracts. We created our state variable `tokenIds` (we use this variable to check current `tokenId` against max supply) using this library, which provides an increment function. So, we can write a function in our mock contract to run a loop and get this state variable’s value to 100. We can call this function in our tests and perform mint to test the constraint of `MAX_SUPPLY`. This method is super clean, efficient, and easy to test.

```
function setTokenIdToMaxSupply() public {
  for(uint256 i = 0; i <= MAX_SUPPLY; i++) {
    _tokenIds.increment();
  }
}
```

![mocks/FigbotMock.sol](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/hJjAUnqp8dK3aplgiinxA.png?height=1080&width=1920)

**Time to test it!**

Now, all we have to do is to call this function `setTokenIdToMaxSupply` inside out test. This will set our `tokenIds` to 100 and if we try to mint after that, we should get “You can not mint anymore”.

```
function testMintAfterMaxSupply() public {  
  vm.startPrank(alice);
  vm.deal(alice, 1 ether); 
  figbot.setTokenIdToMaxSupply();
  vm.expectRevert(bytes("You can not mint anymore"));
  figbot.mint{value: 0.69 ether}();
}
```

Running the tests with `forge test` will give you an \[PASS\] as the contract should not allow users to mint more than 100 tokens.

### Overriding the function:

This is another approach that you will find yourself doing often. However, I recommend using it as little as possible.

With this approach, we `override` our function with “fake” variables. In our case, we will create a new variable called `fakeTokenIds` and use that variable to check our conditions instead of `_tokenIds`. One requirement to override a function is to use the `virtual` keyboard while defining the function you want to override.

So, let’s do that.

1. Make the `mint` function in Figbot.sol a virtual function
2. Create `fakeTokenIds` variable and set its value to 100
3. Override the `mint` function inside FigbotMock.sol by replacing `fakeTokenIds` with `_tokenIds`

![src/Figbot.sol](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/66UKGO0tz1cScpz-q-XLL.png?height=1080&width=1920)

![mocks/FigbotMock.sol](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/5OIA2PNWBv1YF3dXobNeo.png?height=1080&width=1920)

**Time to test it!**

As always, we want to write tests for our contracts to ensure that everything works as it should.

```
function testMintAfterMaxSupply() public {  
  vm.startPrank(alice);
  vm.deal(alice, 1 ether); 
  vm.expectRevert(bytes("You can not mint anymore"));
  figbot.mint{value: 0.69 ether}();
}
```

Keep in mind that I am using foundry cheatcodes here. The first two lines set the user to “alice” and give their wallet a balance of 1 ether. And then, we have an `expectRevert` with the reason for the transaction to fail. In our case, the contract spits out, “You can not mint anymore” if the `MAX_SUPPLY` of 100 is reached.

Run `forge test`, and you can see it \[PASS\] in the results.

## Wrapping up:

I hope this article helped you with learning, and now you can test your smart contracts with 100% coverage. I have shared two approaches for the same scenario. The first one is cleaner and easier to test. It also forces better system design, in my opinion. The second approach has to be used often, but I highly suggest avoiding it to make sure that we don’t mess up anything in our function logic. I hope you find this helpful and feel free to share your thoughts.

title: Manual Operativo del Optimism Collective (v.0.1.1)
body:
*Este documento describe el proceso actual de las propuestas de gobernanza del Optimism Collective. Evolucionará, junto al Collective, con el tiempo.*

## Token House y los holders de OP

La gobernanza en el Optimism Collective comienza con el lanzamiento de la Token House y sus miembros, los holders de OP.

Cómo miembros de la Token House, los holders de OP son responsables de la sumisión, deliberación y votación en los distintos tipos de propuestas de gobernanza del Optimism Collective.

Llevando adelante estas funciones, los holders de OP podrán votar con sus OP directamente, o delegar el poder de voto de sus OP a un tercero elegible.

Token House es solo la primera parte de la [estructura de la gobernanza](https://mirror.xyz/0x3e4865634EC54dFF742E1a7452a456919B8e277b/vqqC7BJqLGuFttA2vYpy-QyJrmoI_-X9LwCffd6Lb6c) de Optimism Collective. Próximamente se inaugurará la Cámara de los Ciudadanos y este Manual Operativo se actualizará en consecuencia.

### Kit de herramientas de gobernanza

Las dos herramientas principales para la gobernanza de Optimism Collective son:

* **Snapshot:** donde todas las propuestas de gobernanza de Token House se envían a votación.
* **[Foro de Optimism:](https://gov.optimism.io/)** Una plataforma de discusión y deliberación sobre propuestas de gobernanza.

### Proceso de propuesta: componentes de una propuesta válida

El ciclo de vida de una propuesta de gobernanza de Token House consta de cuatro fases: **(1)** feedback; **(2)** presentación; **(3)** votación; y **(4)** implementación. Cada fase y sus requisitos asociados se describen a continuación.

### 1 . Feedback

Cualquiera que envíe una propuesta debe hacer un esfuerzo por recopilar feedback de los delegados y la comunidad antes de enviar una propuesta para votación. Hay dos vías principales para el feedback:

**a.** Para feedback ligero o temprano, los autores pueden publicar una propuesta (o una versión abreviada de su propuesta) en el canal **#gov-temp-check** en [Discord](https://discord-gateway.optimism.io/). Este canal está abierto a toda la comunidad de Optimism y puede usarse como una manera fácil de obtener un control rápido de la temperatura.

**b.** Para obtener un feedback formal de los participantes de la gobernanza, los autores pueden publicar una propuesta en el Foro con una etiqueta **\[DRAFT\]** en el título. Esto indica que su propuesta está lista para recibir comentarios de los delegados de Token House. Todos los comentarios de estos dos foros no son vinculantes, pero se espera que los proponentes participen de buena fe. Este paso está diseñado para ayudar a elaborar propuestas reflexivas y efectivas.

Después de incorporar los comentarios, el autor de la propuesta puede eliminar **\[DRAFT\]** del título de la propuesta y avanzar en el envío de la propuesta.

### 2 . Presentación

Para ser elegible para votar, OP holders o su delegado debe presentar una propuesta de gobernanza válida en Token House. Esto significa que la propuesta debe ser:

* Un tipo de propuesta válida. Todas las propuestas de gobernanza v0.1 deben estar dentro de una de las siguientes categorías:
  * Fondo de Gobernanza (Fase 0 o Fase 1)
  * Actualización de protocolo
  * Ajuste por inflación
  * Destitución de un director
  * Asignaciones del Treasury
  * Protecciones de derechos

  Para obtener una descripción más detallada de cada tipo de propuesta, consulte "Proceso de propuesta: por tipo de propuesta" a continuación.
* **Correctamente formateado a la plantilla aplicable.** Cada Tipo de Propuesta tendrá una Plantilla específica asociada en el Foro. Antes de la presentación, el autor de una propuesta debe ajustar su propuesta al formato de la Plantilla aplicable en todos los aspectos materiales. Esto incluirá, por el momento, el requisito de que todas las presentaciones se realicen en inglés.
* **Aprobado por al menos un delegado.** En el transcurso de la discusión y el feedback, al menos un Delegado con más del 0,0005 % de los votos debe indicar que cree que la propuesta está lista para votar. Con el espíritu de minimizar la gobernanza, este documento no codificará un mecanismo de aprobación explícito, pero esperará que los miembros de la comunidad lo interpreten de manera adecuada.
* **Sometida formalmente a votación.** Una semana antes del inicio de cada ciclo de votación, la Fundación iniciará un hilo de Envío de Período de Votación en el Foro. Para enviar formalmente una propuesta para votación, el autor de la propuesta debe **(a)** actualizar el título de su propuesta para comenzar **\[READY\]** o **(b)** agregar un enlace a este hilo de envío del período de votación que apunte a su propuesta en el foro. Al comienzo del próximo Período de Votación, Optimism Foundation enviará todas las propuestas válidas marcadas como listas a Snapshot para votación.

Las propuestas enviadas deben cumplir con todos los criterios anteriores para ser consideradas válidas. Las propuestas no válidas serán descartadas.

Cualquiera que envíe una propuesta puede enviar una versión preliminar de la propuesta para recibir comentarios en el Optimism Forum. Para hacerlo, inclúya **\[Draft\]** en el título de su foro y luego actualice el título de la propuesta una vez que el cuerpo de la propuesta esté finalizado.

### 3 . Votación

Para minimizar los gastos generales, todas las votaciones se realizan en Snapshot a intervalos regulares llamados **períodos de votación**. Los períodos de votación comienzan cada jueves a las 7 p. m. GMT y finalizan 1 semana y 6 días después, el miércoles siguiente a las 7 p. m. GMT. Los tipos de propuestas pueden requerir uno o más períodos de votación antes de que se pueda llegar a una resolución para votar.

Una propuesta en la gobernanza de Token House solo se aprobará si cumple con los siguientes umbrales mínimos de votos:

* **Quórum:** El número mínimo de votos OP totales requeridos para ser emitidos en relación con una propuesta. *Aquí, el quórum se mide como un % del supply total de OP votable.*
  * El supply total de OP votable se determinará en función de una estimación razonable proporcionada por Optimism Foundation antes de cada período de votación.
* **Umbral de aprobación:** El número mínimo de votos OP requeridos para ser emitidos a favor de aprobar una propuesta. El umbral de aprobación de cada propuesta se mide como *un % de votos emitidos para aprobar (en relación con el número total de votos emitidos en relación con) una propuesta.*

**Se tomará un snapshot para determinar el poder de voto** de cada delegado o titular de OP al comienzo de un período de votación determinado.

Según el Tipo de Propuesta, los requisitos exactos de quórum y umbral de aprobación pueden variar.

### 4 . Implementación

Las propuestas que sean rechazadas por invalidez o apoyo insuficiente pueden volver a presentarse. Las propuestas aprobadas se envían a Optimism Foundation para su implementación, como se describe más detalladamente en la sección "Implementación y administración" a continuación.

## Proceso de propuesta: ciclo de vida

Si bien los detalles de una propuesta de gobernanza de Token House en particular pueden variar según el tipo de propuesta, el ciclo de vida de una propuesta generalmente se verá así:

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/3GkOaH7SZPhCQHwde_7Jr.png?height=627&width=1920&size=medium)

## Proceso de propuesta: por tipo de propuesta

Los diferentes requisitos para la presentación y aprobación de cada Tipo de Propuesta se resumen a continuación.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/pdurp0Jj9dzoZn_iFJYF9.png?height=1882&width=821&size=medium)

## Implementación y Administración

En todos los casos, la gobernanza del Optimism Collective pretende llevarse a cabo de conformidad con los términos de su [Constitución de Trabajo](https://gov.optimism.io/t/working-constitution-of-the-optimism-collective/55/23?u=axlvaz), el espíritu de su [Código de Conducta](https://gov.optimism.io/t/code-of-conduct/5/3) y la búsqueda de su [Visión Optimista](https://mirror.xyz/0x3e4865634EC54dFF742E1a7452a456919B8e277b/G-Ss-W78Vfrckz2MkHHnWiB7wFaH2D5nsbh6KE5c050). The Optimism Foundation administrará este proceso como se describe a continuación.

### Administración

The Optimism Foundation facilitará la administración de los procedimientos de gobernanza descritos en este Manual operativo con el objetivo de garantizar que los OP holders puedan participar de manera eficiente y efectiva en la gobernanza de Token House. Dichos servicios administrativos pueden incluir:

* Moderación de las propuestas de gobernanza para garantizar que se presenten y voten válidamente;
* Eliminación de propuestas que parezcan razonablemente fraudulentas, orientadas a correos no deseados, difamatorias, odiosas o inapropiadas o inconsistentes con los valores del Colectivo;
* Supervisión de los votos, el suministro de tokens votables y los períodos de votación con el fin de determinar si se cumplen los quórumes y los umbrales de aprobación;
* Gestión de propuestas contradictorias entre sí que se presentan simultáneamente o muy cerca unas de otras;
* Administración del mantenimiento de la red, como corrección de errores de emergencia o reversión de versiones (con o sin voto de gobierno); y
* Las demás que la Fundación estime convenientes en relación con las anteriores.

### Implementación

Las propuestas de gobernanza de Token House aprobadas se enviarán a Optimism Foundation para su implementación.

Al recibir una propuesta aprobada, Optimism Foundation determinará si la propuesta es segura, consistente con los propósitos de la Fundación y el Colectivo, y si se puede implementar de manera legalmente compatible.

* En caso afirmativo, la Fundación actuará con diligencia y de forma comercialmente razonable para que la propuesta se lleve a cabo.
* De no ser así, la Fundación puede eliminar la propuesta para volver a presentarla o hacer que la propuesta se implemente con ciertas medidas de seguridad, a su discreción, y junto con una explicación al Colectivo de por qué la propuesta fue rechazada o limitada.

La Optimism Foundation emprenderá este trabajo ministerial con miras a descentralizar cada vez más su papel con el tiempo.

## Enmiendas

Los procedimientos descritos en este Manual operativo entrarán en vigencia en el momento del Airdrop #1 y se ajustarán más adelante en relación con una serie de experimentos de gobernanza. Estos cambios incluyen, entre otros, la introducción de la Cámara de los Ciudadanos y la adición, eliminación y modificación de Tipos de propuestas y reglas relacionadas con los procesos de votación. Cualquier actualización no administrativa del Manual de operaciones se reflejará con un nuevo número de versión en la parte superior de este documento, momento en el que entrará en vigencia la versión actualizada.

title: Why not let legacy institutions fail?
body:
The seed of this article came when I read Balaji’s excellent post on [founding v. inheriting](https://1729.com/founding-vs-inheriting) institutions. That post got me wondering what would happen if we just let bloated legacy institutions fail. I am not an anarchist and my hope is not for chaos to prevail.

Social and economic institutions play a valuable role to help society work. We need them. But they all default to a top-down, bureaucratic format that increases costs (and inefficiencies) over time. I’d love to find examples when that trend was successfully reversed.

I can’t help but wonder how much time, money and effort is spent in maintaining  the crumbling status quo. People in many countries are feeling short-changed, and trust towards social and economic institutions has been declining.

Instead of trying to keep afloat what we have, wouldn’t our collective time, money and efforts be best applied towards new, bottom-up institutions that are purpose-built for efficiency and accountability? Would these not better serve society today if we can free ourselves from our legacy? Even if the answer is no, asking the question is in order.

There is no easy way to A/B test this unfortunately. My bet is that we have a structural issue and we grossly under-estimate how much ineffective most of these bloated organizations actually are in achieving anything. Similar to un-managed technical debt, are we tied down by societal debt, and can we “re-platform” society in order to get on a more attractive path?

The power governments have to tax people is a form of monopoly. Governments do not compete with anyone for the tax revenue. Taxpayers can’t decide to pay their taxes to B instead of A given their track records. That is inertia, and that is an issue. Tax payers are captive, they can’t do much about this situation. Yes you can move abroad in some cases, but most people won’t or can’t. Given that rent-seeking type of arrangement, governments do not have the right incentives to stay lean and to maximize impact.

Generally, when institutions get older, the cost of simply maintaining current operations goes up a little (or a lot lately) every year. They are not getting to economies of scale. They have no need to remain nimble as long as they can coerce their citizens.

As a thought experiment: what would happen if we let legacy institutions fail? Would citizens self-coordinate to fill in the void? Would chaos eventually return to a new, fitter order on which societies work?

**Institutions going to zero?!** It might sound batshit crazy, but it might just be history repeat itself, according to [Dalio’s Principles for Dealing with the Changing World Order: Why Nations Succeed and Fail.](https://www.amazon.ca/Changing-World-Order-Nations-Succeed/dp/1982160276) Some events and cycles are too slow for anyone to be around the next time they come around. The death of legacy institutions is inevitable, if history is a guide. Everything in the natural world follows natural cycles of birth, growth, decay and death.  Plants, animals, planets, stars, civilizations, you get it.

A bright spot in the Covid-19 pandemic has been how resilient and innovative we have been with regards to global-scale social experiments. The crisis gave us a clear focal point to channel our ideas and ambition collectively.

We went from natural order to total chaos to a new-and-improved order in under 2 years (at least the economy kept moving and we gave people vaccines).  That gives me hope that while there is always turbulence with social and economic changes, we’d quickly find a way out of the void and chaos that old institutions would leave behind.

I want to see a better incentive model for managing social institutions: aligned incentives (aka skin in the game), transparency, efficiency. I often wonder, what would happen if I moved to a tax-free country and elected to pay the same rate as I would pay previously in Canada, but give the money to charities of my choice? In other words, what if could decentralize how individuals allocate the money for society’s benefit?

What if we ended up on a better allocation model than current institutions? On one hand there is so much money in the economy, and on the other hand governments are running in the red, a lot of people can’t save anything at all, and non-profits struggle to make ends meet. How can both such abundance and scarcity co-exist at the same time?

Our societal approach to allocation and incentives have to be part of the problem and the solution. One way to tackle this was illustrated in this interesting [paper](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=4105763), explaining what primitives we might need for a decentralized society to take form.

title: HASH DAO Whitepaper
body:
**Highly Autonomous Systems of Horticulture ($HASH)**

**The World‘s First Cannabis DAO**

*Updated : May 2022*

**Mission**

To cultivate Web3 community horticulture for the future of the cannabis space.

HASH DAO provides the first unified DAO solution for craft cannabis operators, industry professionals, investors, and marginalized communities interested in the cannabis marketplace.

HASH DAO has been created to allow these parties integration into the emerging technologies of blockchain and Web3 into the cannabis industry.

We start by partnering with Uncle Mac's to create the world’s first DAO cannabis company and community tooling of horticulture. Building a growing compilation of automation protocols using smart contracts. 

HASH DAO Governance seeks to be the future industry standard.

**Problem**

Funding for a successful craft cannabis brand with artisanal quality creates struggles to navigate the extractive nature of the traditional corporate company structure. Typically the capital solutions available often compromise the integrity and quality of the products at the expense of the small brands reputation, consumers, and the Earth.

Malpractice and gatekeeping of the cannabis industry has traditionally maximized profits at the cost of the plant or people, and in turn have provided barriers to entry to craft cannabis farmers and the BIPOC community.

*Barriers of Entry + (Profit > People) = Current State of the Cannabis Space*

**Solution**

Merging Web3 technologies with the cannabis space and creating decentralized and democratized opportunities for companies to raise capital.

HASH DAO : Utilizing smart contracts to automate and democratize production, supply chain, and governance in the cannabis & psychedelic industry.

**Introduction**

The multi-billion dollar cannabis industry is entering it’s boom phase as support for [U.S. federal legalization](https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/3617) grows and global cannabis markets continue to come online. The cannabis space is estimated to grow to over [$200 Billion by 2030](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20220203005879/en/Global-Cannabis-Market-Size-Forecast-Report-2021-A-176-Billion-by-2030---Growing-Legalization-of-Medical-Cannabis-in-Various-Countries-Driving-Growth---ResearchAndMarkets.com--) as predicted by Berkshire Hathaway. The majority of the craft cannabis industry, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the consumer, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly penalized small legacy growers. Incarceration of marginalized communities for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in. Certain strains go on to become culturally iconic that generate massive value. Often times the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

Current Stakeholders in the Cannabis Space :

* Breeders, Growers, & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

Although track-and-trace is currently implemented, most cannabis brands are not completely transparent with their grow methods and techniques of production. There is also massive risk for current cannabis businesses as they have become targets for robberies the past few years. Legal brands are facing counterfeits and knock-offs in the black market. With the integration of digital identities, NFTs/Web3 purchasing, and automation, many of these problems are easily solved.

**How it Works**

Create community-ownership of the vertically-integrated HASH DAO supply chain of production, processing, distributing, and operating on-chain craft cannabis compliance geared toward Web3 adoption. Information, data security, and their applications are essential for business optimization and transparency.

Although there are many ERP solutions for the industry already, our governance will be centered around cannabis supply chain and DeFi dApps that utilize NFT-based SKU’s to generate active product data and create on-chain interactions that comply with ESG metrics, paving the way for global regulations and the future of the cannabis space.

> *ON-CHAIN SUPPLY NFTs + ACTIVE INVENTORY TRACKING + CRYPTO TRANSACTIONS = Web3 Point of Sale (PoS)*

**Data Privacy & Security**

Privacy is essential to any business. Surprisingly, it is almost nonexistent in the blockchain ecosystem. For example, Bitcoin started out with privacy as a goal but was subverted and now is very public by using \[chain analytics companies\](https://bitcoinist.com/yes-your-bitcoin-transactions-can-be-tracked-and-here-are-the-companies that-are-doing-it/.). It's like having your bank account available to the public where the public cannot access your money but they can see everything you are doing. The same is true of smart contract platforms like Ethereum.

Hash DAO will use the most private smart contract platform soon-to-be available, [DERO](https://www.dero.com/).

Bitcoin's privacy problem was solved by the cryptocurrency coin Monero. Similarly, Ethereum’s privacy problem is solved by the token DERO.

Many blockchain projects, both cryptocurrency coins and and smart contract platforms using tokens, claim privacy but in fact are not. They offer a privacy option at best. This in fact defeats true privacy which only exists when the project offers *privacy by default at the protocol level*.

**On-Chain Protocols + Smart Contracts = The Automated Horticulture of Tomorrow**

Creating a future:

* Geared to the love and cultivation of the plant and Mother Earth
* Onboarding marginalized leaders and creatives onto the blockchain
* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

**HASH DAO = Power Back in Your Hands**

HASH DAO Governance is the future of the industry standard, and to do this we will start by partnering with one successful Emerald Triangle, Northern California craft cannabis-brand with community-staking of its future scaling of operations and expanding a compilation of automation protocols through smart contracts.

Reinvention of the Horticulture Supply Chain and Data Distribution via smart contracts that allow for automation and help individuals to create ownership over community-led projects, intellectual property, digital assets, and dApps.

Developing Horticulture Public Goods :

HASH DAO is an organization that is dedicated to creating a network of cannabis growers and educators. We aim to promote the use of horticulture, farming and natural medicine as a means for collective healing and wellness. A cannabis research, development and production partnership. This DAO will address both the intellectual property and craft standards of local microgrowers, processors, home growers and people interested in horticultural education as well as providing funding for research projects into genetic diversity and marijuana's medicinal applications.

title: One Smpl Trick
body:
9–5 metaverses and weekend metaverses, touch grass metaverses and [touch simulation](https://www.ft.com/content/4be5677b-bc03-4e46-bbbb-68074e8dda6c) metaverses, living metaverses and dying metaverses. Silicon Valley tells a story about the world to come that says everything there will be just as it is here. Just as our room is now, so it will be in the world to come; where our baby sleeps now, there too it will sleep in the other world. And the clothes we wear in this world, those too we will wear there. Everything will be as it is now, just differently textured.

This surface familiarity, however, belies the novel forms of visuality that animate the metaverse. Beyond the illusory layer of avatars and environments, techniques such as subtle gaze direction and foveated rendering exploit research on human visual cognition, while computer vision algorithms are refined by data synthesized using computer graphics. For humans, these new images operate below the threshold of perception; for machines, they help synchronize user performance across worlds. Since synthetic data is diverse and perfectly labeled by design, synthetically-trained models generalize better than models trained on real data.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Z0PeTXBZUBO9hyIKVK9T3.jpeg?height=883&width=1365&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

SMPLverse NFTs use facial recognition to retrieve data synthesized by Microsoft to develop face tracking algorithms for its mixed reality headsets. Like many pfp projects, the Microsoft dataset uses procedural generation to randomly create and render faces without any manual intervention. The images combine a generative 3D face model with a library of artist-created assets—including textures, hair, and clothing—and SMPL, a body mesh used to animate avatars in virtual environments. Although verisimilitude is formally irrelevant to machine learning, it remains the only method of achieving functional equivalence between real and synthetic data.

Visually, the training images suggest identity play, emulating the avatars whose naturalism they are meant to enhance. Their effect, however, is to attune algorithms ever more precisely to users’ physical selves: the dataset expresses how users appear *to* virtual environments as much as how they appear *in* them. The minting process, which matches your own face to a smpl, elaborates the tension between freedom and constraint—even a pool of 100,000 images is too small to produce consistent matches.

The market-driven development of immersive technologies constitutes its own form of vision. By fractionalizing Microsoft’s dataset into NFTs, SMPLverse inverts its function, redistributing the metaverse’s centralized assets through its paradigmatic decentralized property form.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Ua2pugKf_c16nk4xt8MhA.png?height=512&width=1024&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

### Details

* There are 511 tokens available to mint.
* Each token allows you to submit one image through our webcam interface. Your submitted image will be written to the token as a hash. Our facial recognition model uses this hash to match your image to a smpl.
* When the image is matched, it receives one attribute: confidence. Confidence assesses the likelihood that your image matches the smpl you receive. Confidence is a declining measure: as more smpls are matched, your likelihood of receiving a high confidence match decreases. Conversely, your likelihood of receiving a smpl with stranger visual attributes increases.
* 7 rare smpls have an additional “head pose cluster” attribute, which entitles them each to 4.14% of secondary revenue. These rare smpls form a group of images clustered by head pose. As more rare smpls are matched, the bounds of the cluster will sharpen. To acquire a rare smpl, token holders must recognize the same patterns that a facial recognition system trained on the dataset would be optimized to recognize.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/qWWsezFM2rbJ0wyPkWdJQ.jpg?height=288&width=249&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

SMPLverse is launching June 24, 2022 at [smplverse.xyz](https://smplverse.xyz/)

Please check site for local timezones.

Main sale price is 0.2 ETH. Presale price is 0.18 ETH.

Find more details on our [Twitter](https://twitter.com/smplverse) and our [Discord](https://discord.gg/2hWDykfUdq).

title: Web3 Product Design Mindsets
body:
### 1. Driven by Curiosity

> *We are curious, open, ask “WH questions” continuously, and change the perspective in order to look at things from various sides.*

This sort of curiosity is especially important in the web3 space, as innovations are happening rapidly with lots of resources and talents going into this space. New tools and protocols are constantly surfacing, and the only way to keep up with the space is the relentless curiosity to learn, experiment and question these products. As product builders in the web3 space, the best way to learn is to get our hands dirty and immerse ourselves as a native user.

This means trying out various blockchain networks and ecosystems, participating in DeFi products, becoming a member of a DAO, and experiencing various NFT marketplace and auction mechanisms. Through this journey, it is possible that we may stumble and make some mistakes, but it is all part of the learning experience. And as product builders, we have the power to create and improve these experiences.

### 2. Accept Complexity

> *We explore the key complex systems, and accept uncertainty and the fact that complex system problems demand complex solutions.*

There is no doubt that web3 space is still at its nascent stage, and building products is like exploring uncharted territory. It is important to embrace that uncertainty as the norm and come up with creative solutions to hide the complexities or better explain the benefits of blockchain technology.

One way to explore how product builders have attempted in coming up with solutions to various complex system problems is by reading the whitepapers in the web3 space. Not only do we get a glimpse into the minds of these product builders, we may also draw inspiration from existing solutions and implement our twist to suit our needs.

### 3. Focus on the People

> *We focus on the human being, build empathy, and are mindful when exploring their needs.*

The key to scaling and driving adoption for web3 products is driving product-market fit. This requires us to focus on the needs of our users by building up a deep-rooted empathy and embodying an attitude of pure curiosity in need-finding, this way, everything we learn can guide us to human-centered solutions resulting in a better user experience.

Being a good designer in web3 need to know how users come into contact with specific products and why they interact with them. Before beginning the design of a product, we must be in contact with the users on social networks or in the real world in order to get an authentic picture of their behaviour and needs. This also means doing extensive user research and gathering user feedback throughout the process. Web3 innovation only works when we have internalized the needs of our users and developed a thorough understanding of them.

### 4. Experiment and Iterate

> *We build and test iteratively to understand, learn, and solve problems in the context of the user.*

The experiment and iterative approach are fundamental to a lean startup methodology introduced by Eric Ries, which he defined as “an institution of people organized to make a new produce or service in incredibly uncertain circumstances.” As builders in the web3 space, it is important to draw on user feedback to guide and speed up the product’s iterative development.

One way to do so is by creating a social space (i.e., discord group) for users to engage with the community, share their thoughts, and collect feedback. Early blockchain products often have a high barrier of entry,  and only a small group of tech-savvy experts are onboarded. By building products through continuous experiments and iterations, we ensure that these digital products are truly addressing the goals, needs, and pain points of our potential users.

### 5. Develop Process Awareness

> *We know where we stand in the design thinking process and develop a feeling for the “groan zone” to change the mindset through facilitation in a targeted way.*

An important factor of success in design thinking is to know where we stand in the process. There are generally two mental states during this process: either we develop many new ideas (divergence) or we focus on and limit ourselves to a narrow set of functionalities and solutions (convergence). At what point in time have we gathered sufficient information, and how many ideas are necessary before we begin to transform the cavalcade of ideas into possible solutions?

### 6. Reflect on Actions

> *We reflect on our way of thinking, our actions, and attitudes because they have an impact on what we do and on the assumptions we make.*

It is important to reflect on ourselves and realize we don’t necessarily represent the people for whom we develop our innovation. And even if we do, we must proceed with great caution when transferring our needs to others.

### Conclusion

Embracing the above mindsets will be good for designers interested in building simple mental models of the technologies that underlie Web3. I believe it’s important to have a basic understanding of what is happening on the backend to be an effective designer. Building this understanding, along with what you’ve already learned, is all the preparation you need to become a Web3 product designer.

This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly penalized small legacy growers. Incarceration of marginalized communities for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

Hash DAO will use the most private smart contract platform soon-to-be available, [DERO](https://www.dero.com/).

HASH DAO provides the first unified DAO solution for craft cannabis operators, industry professionals, investors, and marginalized communities interested in the cannabis marketplace.

HASH DAO has been created to allow these parties integration into the emerging technologies of blockchain and Web3 into the cannabis industry.

We start by partnering with an IRL (in-real-life) award-winning, craft cannabis company which includes real estate acquisition. 

HASH DAO seeks to be the industry standard.

**Problem**

Funding for a successful craft cannabis brand with artisanal quality creates struggles to navigate the extractive nature of the traditional corporate company structure. Typically the capital solutions available often compromise the integrity and quality of the products at the expense of the small brands reputation, consumers, and the Earth.

Malpractice and gatekeeping of the cannabis industry has traditionally maximized profits at the cost of the plant or people, and in turn have provided barriers to entry to craft cannabis farmers and the BIPOC community.

*Barriers of Entry + (Profit > People) = Current State of the Cannabis Space*

**Solution**

Merging Web3 technologies with the cannabis space and creating decentralized and democratized opportunities for companies to raise capital.

HASH DAO : Utilizing smart contracts to automate and democratize production, supply chain, and governance in the cannabis & psychedelic industry.

**Introduction**

The multi-billion dollar cannabis industry is entering it’s boom phase as support for [U.S. federal legalization](https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/3617) grows and global cannabis markets continue to come online. The cannabis space is estimated to grow to over [$200 Billion by 2030](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20220203005879/en/Global-Cannabis-Market-Size-Forecast-Report-2021-A-176-Billion-by-2030---Growing-Legalization-of-Medical-Cannabis-in-Various-Countries-Driving-Growth---ResearchAndMarkets.com--) as predicted by Berkshire Hathaway. The majority of the craft cannabis industry, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the consumer, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly penalized small legacy growers. Incarceration of marginalized communities for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in. Certain strains go on to become culturally iconic that generate massive value. Often times the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

Current Stakeholders in the Cannabis Space :

* Breeders, Growers, & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

Although track-and-trace is currently implemented, most cannabis brands are not completely transparent with their grow methods and techniques of production. There is also massive risk for current cannabis businesses as they have become targets for robberies the past few years. Legal brands are facing counterfeits and knock-offs in the black market. With the integration of digital identities, NFTs/Web3 purchasing, and automation, many of these problems are easily solved.

**How it Works**

Create community-ownership of the vertically-integrated HASH DAO supply chain of production, processing, distributing, and operating on-chain craft cannabis compliance geared toward Web3 adoption. Information, data security, and their applications are essential for business optimization and transparency.

Although there are many ERP solutions for the industry already, our governance will be centered around cannabis supply chain and DeFi dApps that utilize NFT-based SKU’s to generate active product data and create on-chain interactions that comply with ESG metrics, paving the way for global regulations and the future of the cannabis space.

> *ON-CHAIN SUPPLY NFTs + ACTIVE INVENTORY TRACKING + CRYPTO TRANSACTIONS = Web3 Point of Sale (PoS)*

**Data Privacy & Security**

Privacy is essential to any business. Surprisingly, it is almost nonexistent in the blockchain ecosystem. For example, Bitcoin started out with privacy as a goal but was subverted and now is very public by using \[chain analytics companies\](https://bitcoinist.com/yes-your-bitcoin-transactions-can-be-tracked-and-here-are-the-companies that-are-doing-it/.). It's like having your bank account available to the public where the public cannot access your money but they can see everything you are doing. The same is true of smart contract platforms like Ethereum.

Hash DAO will use the most private smart contract platform soon-to-be available, [DERO](https://www.dero.com/).

Bitcoin's privacy problem was solved by the cryptocurrency coin Monero. Similarly, Ethereum’s privacy problem is solved by the token DERO.

Many blockchain projects, both cryptocurrency coins and and smart contract platforms using tokens, claim privacy but in fact are not. They offer a privacy option at best. This in fact defeats true privacy which only exists when the project offers *privacy by default at the protocol level*.

**On-Chain Protocols + Smart Contracts = The Automated Horticulture of Tomorrow**

Creating a future:

* Geared to the love and cultivation of the plant and Mother Earth
* Onboarding marginalized leaders and creatives onto the blockchain
* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

**HASH DAO = Power Back in Your Hands**

HASH DAO Governance is the future of the industry standard, and to do this we will start by partnering with one successful Emerald Triangle, Northern California craft cannabis-brand with community-staking of its future scaling of operations and expanding a compilation of automation protocols through smart contracts.

Reinvention of the Horticulture Supply Chain and Data Distribution via smart contracts that allow for automation and help individuals to create ownership over community-led projects, intellectual property, digital assets, and dApps.

Developing Horticulture Public Goods :

We aim to promote the use of horticulture, farming and natural medicine as a means for collective healing and wellness. This DAO will address both the intellectual property and craft standards of local microgrowers, processors, home growers and people interested in horticultural education as well as providing funding for research projects into genetic diversity and marijuana's medicinal applications.

Another utility is that HASH DAO is a tokenized equity fundraising tool. HASH DAO's mission is to become a community-governed organization tasked with helping small companies fund themselves and achieve liquidity. A decentralized community-governance solution for HASH DAO that includes a market-driven, tokenized oracle for the  liquidity, yield-farming and major-user decisions.

**First Wins for HASH DAO**

> “Community Ownership of Physical and Digital Assets”

Minting a multi-tiered HASH DAO NFT with the top governance tier going for $10 K, raising a total of $11.5 M for an initial HASH DAO treasury. As funds become available, proceeds will immediately go to partnering with South Face Mangement to purchase over 30 acres in Mendocino and 40+ acres Humbolt County. This will include the scaling of a vertically-integrated nursery, farm, hash processing, and soon-to-launch retail of award-winning legacy products under Uncle Mac’s brand and South Face Farms Management.

**Project #1 :**  Carry out renovation on the farm and nursery to ensure full-scale ESG-metric compliance and how to bring all aspects of the farm and it’s production on-chain, from SKU NFT’s to utilizing energy consumption data for carbon credit checks. Partnering with Uncle Mac’s, a Northern California craft cannabis brand, & South Face Management, parent company to Flower Wheel Nursery, South Face Farms Cultivation, and Uncle Mac’s brand.

**Project #2 :** Onboard visual and 3D artists who will design branding and assets for the Metaverse and we develop cross-chain NFT’s to be dropped on various play-to-earn games. We will also be acquiring digital plots of real estate to build “Metaverse farms” and “digital dispensaries” where a user can view the product, find out all of it’s information, and have it eventually delivered through an on-chain transaction. Along with digital land we will also be investing in domain names, including various strain names, cannabis celebrities, and psychedelic culture. Explore liquidity pools and yield farming with assets and treasury.

**Project #3 :** For the third project, we’ll be launching Uncle Mac's HASH House is an Emerald Triangle legacy project. This on-chain Hash House is the home lab for Uncle Mac’s production. We will also operate as a wholesale fresh frozen supply chain solution for transportation, storage, distribution and hash toll processing throughout the greater Emerald Triangle area.

**Project #4** : Getting HASH in your hands. This is our farm-to-table craft cannabis buyers club providing direct-to-consumer access to exclusive SKU’s from legacy brands in the Emerald Triangle. This will include obtaining a retail and event license to launch Nephew’s Automated.

**Project #5 :** Aggregating a library of horticulture public goods & building the Biodiversity BIPOC Glamping Learning Initiative; start building Marijuana for Minorities Program to co-create HASH University creating content with some of the best small-batch growers and washers in the industry. (Community Online Education)

**Project #6 :** Nephew’s will be applying for its event space license building the foundation for Akasha, an immersive psychedelic A/R Lounge for BIPOC community healing. The distribution and delivery will be a warehouse that will have an on-chain ESG-metric system in the back and a public access immersive art space in the front. We will also be looking into developing a portfolio of boutique cannabis bud and breakfasts in emerging global cannabis markets.

**Project #7 :** We will be finding ERP solutions to develop state-of-the-art horticulture automation and Web3 technologies, based upon on-chain governance and compliance, to pave the way for the international industry standard by working towards meeting ESG-metric compliance. Our final goal is developing complete automation systems without compromising craft horticulture. From driverless deliveries, farm drone surveillance & data collection to utilize machine-learning and AI and to understand buyer behavior, horticulture improvements, growth optimization, etc.

**Opportunity**

title: One Smpl Trick
body:
9–5 metaverses and weekend metaverses, touch grass metaverses and [touch simulation](https://www.ft.com/content/4be5677b-bc03-4e46-bbbb-68074e8dda6c) metaverses, living metaverses and dying metaverses. Silicon Valley tells a story about the world to come that says everything there will be just as it is here. Just as our room is now, so it will be in the world to come; where our baby sleeps now, there too it will sleep in the other world. And the clothes we wear in this world, those too we will wear there. Everything will be as it is now, just differently textured.

This surface familiarity belies the novel forms of visuality that animate the metaverse. Beyond the illusory layer of avatars and environments, techniques such as subtle gaze direction and foveated rendering exploit research on human visual cognition, while computer vision algorithms are refined by data synthesized using computer graphics. For humans, these new images operate below the threshold of perception; for machines, they help synchronize user performance between worlds. Since synthetic data is diverse and perfectly labeled by design, synthetically-trained models generalize better than models trained on real data.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Z0PeTXBZUBO9hyIKVK9T3.jpeg?height=883&width=1365&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

SMPLverse NFTs use facial recognition to retrieve data synthesized by Microsoft to develop face tracking algorithms for its mixed reality headsets. Like many pfp projects, the Microsoft dataset uses procedural generation to randomly create and render faces without any manual intervention. The images combine a generative 3D face model with a library of artist-created assets—including textures, hair, and clothing—and SMPL, a body mesh used to animate avatars in virtual environments. Although verisimilitude is formally irrelevant to machine learning, it remains the only method of achieving functional equivalence between real and synthetic data.

Visually, the training images suggest identity play, emulating the avatars whose naturalism they are meant to enhance. Their effect, however, is to attune algorithms ever more precisely to users’ physical selves: the dataset expresses how users appear *to* virtual environments as much as how they appear *in* them. The minting process, which matches your own face to a smpl, elaborates the tension between freedom and constraint—even a pool of 100,000 images is too small to produce consistent matches.

The market-driven development of immersive technologies constitutes its own form of vision. By fractionalizing Microsoft’s dataset into NFTs, SMPLverse inverts its function, redistributing the metaverse’s centralized assets through its paradigmatic decentralized property form.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Ua2pugKf_c16nk4xt8MhA.png?height=512&width=1024&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

### Details

* There are 511 tokens available to mint.
* Each token allows you to submit one image through our webcam interface. Your submitted image will be written to the token as a hash. Our facial recognition model uses this hash to match your image to a smpl.
* When the image is matched, it receives one attribute: confidence. Confidence assesses the likelihood that your image matches the smpl you receive. Confidence is a declining measure: as more smpls are matched, your likelihood of receiving a high confidence match decreases. Conversely, your likelihood of receiving a smpl with stranger visual attributes increases.
* 7 rare smpls have an additional “head pose cluster” attribute, which entitles them each to 4.14% of secondary revenue. These rare smpls form a group of images clustered by head pose. As more rare smpls are matched, the bounds of the cluster will sharpen. To acquire a rare smpl, token holders must recognize the same patterns that a facial recognition system trained on the dataset would be optimized to recognize.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/qWWsezFM2rbJ0wyPkWdJQ.jpg?height=288&width=249&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&)

SMPLverse is launching June 24, 2022 at [smplverse.xyz](https://smplverse.xyz/)

Please check site for local timezones.

Main sale price is 0.2 ETH. Presale price is 0.18 ETH.

Find more details on our [Twitter](https://twitter.com/smplverse) and our [Discord](https://discord.gg/2hWDykfUdq).

title: The Firewall Saga - Synopsis
body:
Set twenty-five thousand years after the apocalypse, The Firewall Saga tells the story of Earth divided in two by a wall of nuclear fire that encircles the equator.

The Northern Hemisphere has been turned into a radioactive wasteland with most of its landmass left inhospitable to life and vast swathes of the oceans boiled off into the atmosphere. The relatively advanced infrastructure of the early 21st century nation-states allowed small pockets of human civilization to survive with much of their scientific knowledge intact. Over the subsequent millennia, the northern survivors have managed to consolidate and advance the progress of civilization. Unfortunately, the reality of scorched earth has pushed the boundaries of what even the most advanced scientific understanding can achieve, and their survival now depends on crossing the Firewall into the unknown Southern Hemisphere...

...where the effects of the creation of the Firewall could not have been more different. The initial cataclysm was as devastating to the South as it was to the North; however, radiation was limited to a narrow band close to the equator, leaving much of the landmass habitable. With the near-total destruction of human civilization, the southern hemisphere's eco-systems have been able to bounce back from the cataclysm and have turned the south into a thriving biome. Humanity has managed to hang on, but the progress of the 21st century was lost and the cultures that now thrive are tribal and barbaric.

Book 1 of the saga, Emberlight, tells the story of the Northerner's attempts to breach the Firewall and explore the South, following the adventures of Antigua and her robotic steed as they explore this uncharted part of the world. It follows her encounters with southern natives whose primitive, nomadic ways are as alien to her as her cyber-enhanced bio-armour and robot horse are to them. Can these two races, once a single world population, reunite and thrive again?

Or will the clash of cultures result in a global war?
